title: @Stashu - Cassiopeia still isn't where she needs to be.
body:
The effort in 4.21 is commendable, but despite these efforts, Cassiopeia is still not what she needs to be thematically and in game play.
First of all, while the tweaked passive does technically kick in faster, again, this is an element I do not like nor do many other players of Cassiopeia. Her strength is still locked out until milestones, now governed by time more than anything. In the matches I've played with the new numbers, it still takes more time than necessary to get her to where she needs to be to not be dead weight against champions who can quickly overwhelm her while she is still struggling to bring herself to their level. Regardless of whether or not she's "OP" and an end game melter of faces, this is not the direction that Cassiopeia should have been pushed into. 
Secondly, the overloading of E is becoming an issue. I'm sure you've heard the KISS acronym before. Keep It Simple, Stashu. E at the moment is excessively overloaded and does entirely too much. As many have mentioned before, we don't like an E centric Cassiopeia kit with her poisons as an afterthought. An amp on E is appreciated, but it doesn't get back to the problems she has - she is a flimsy mage with pitiful range with E, and forcing her into close proximity against almost any other mid retards her effectiveness. With her posions only lasting 2-3 seconds unless the opponent is camping in a Miasma, this amp is ineffective at giving power back to her poisons, and only serves to inflame her mana problems. 
That leads us to W and R. W is effectively useless, even with the amp. 13 damage amplified by 20% barely breaks 15 damage. Almost all champions can soak it up and ignore Miasma entirely. This is a problem, especially when we have other champions like Teemo, Singed, and Twitch who have more effective poisons than she does, the poison mage. That's just wrong. R has major issues in that there is a cast time. No one else has this weird, uncalled for cast time on a spell like this. Unlike champions like Zyra, who has a projectile multitarget root, Cassiopeia has a point blank stun that is akin to Lissandra's W and shouldn't have a cast time. Why does her looking at someone have a cast time? In so many instances where her R should have saved me, it hasn't, because that uncalled for cast time has given the foe too much time to end me. An ultimate should be an ultimate, not some gappy low rate spell that is easily thwarted; this especially since Cassiopeia has to be point blank to use it. Please fix it.
And finally, one other major issue with Cassiopeia is her death animation. On every single skin other than Jade Fang, when she breaks apart, the model reverts back to the old classic model. Fix it. This has been an issue since well before her rework.

As a reccomendation, strip E of all of it's bells and whistles. Return it to it's pre-rework state. Drop her passive, give her ratios back to her Q, W, and R, and give her a new passive. Here's my suggestion:
Whenever Cassiopeia kills a poisoned unit, she gains 1% of her max mana. Every fourth spell cast has 10% spell vamp.
We simply want Cassiopeia to be a poison mage. As in a mage who's sole purpose is to cast poisons at people. We done like an E focused kit. Please fix her.

That was intentional by the part of whomever coded it. And it's pretty easy to see why:

Originally, Cassiopeia's E would reset to 0.5 seconds **upon damaging a poisoned enemy**.

Then, a 0.7 second reset was added **upon casting Twin Fang on a poisoned enemy**. The original reset was not changed, however, so if the cooldown was above 0.5 seconds it would reset to 0.5 seconds upon damaging a poisoned enemy.

However, Twin Fang **has a missile speed**. The 0.7 second reset compensates for the missile speed, thus making long-ranged Twin Fangs and short-ranged Twin Fangs have, most of the time, the cooldown they ought to have, but adding a bit of extra reliability should the poison tick away in the transit period of Twin Fang.

The E timer was being reset to 0.7 seconds **intentionally** because otherwise Cassiopeia's Twin Fang would be getting a large buff.

>Target Poisoned? 'A' is now true.

>'A' is true? Set cooldown to 0.5 seconds.

Just my two cents, but the idea of a full fledged poison mage is incredibly difficult to balance and implement. By its nature, a poison mage uses its DoTS to do damage while staying safely out of the way. Problem is, this is incredibly frustrating for the opponent. Give her Q too much power, and she can drop it all day with no real risk to herself. And the only thing the opponent can do is hope they have a competent jungler. Make her W too strong, and she can waveclear with incredible power. At the least, the E change forces her to be more interactive with her opponent, forcing her to take risks for her actions. The rework is certainly by no means a great product, but I do believe Stashu is giving it his best shot.
On a side note, Cass more of a 'snake mage' than a full on 'poison mage' pre-work. And snakes do come in the venomous and non-venomous varieties.

> We simply want Cassiopeia to be a poison mage. As in a mage who's sole purpose is to cast poisons at people. We don't like an E focused kit. Please fix her.

This is the main point. I'm on board with you, but I really want to call out that:
A mage whose sole purpose is to cast poisons at people does not necessarily have to

* Have a strong early game
* Be long range
* Do mostly AoE damage
* Have short cast times, etc.

Going forward with Cassiopeia, the core goalset includes focusing the kit more on her poisons, but it does not necessarily include making her a long-range-focused or early-game-focused mage.

 We've got her to a much more playable state (perhaps even a bit too strong), but there's still more to be done feeling-wise. 

This might mean shifting power from her short range ability into her longer range ones, or just making her shorter range ability different and more of a core poison itself, as all of these are viable options in making a poison mage.

I'll definitely be sure to bring the discussion here when we start to get a bit more traction on the paths we're thinking of taking.

All of this would be reasonable except for the fact that your rework of her took the single element of her kit that wasn't poison related (aside from a setup) and turned that into the core focus of her kit. There are already numerous characters with spamable burst. There are next to none that specialize in DOTs. 
If you had chosen to change her DOTs into single targets rather than AoE, that would have been fine. If those single target poisons were her kit focus and the bulk of her damage output, that would retain her identity as a poison mage. I've never said, nor have others, that she absolutely has to have AoE poisons to retain her identity. The AoE is something that was fun, but the core principle here is that she needs to have a focus on poison. Same holds true for her range, but in that case, if you are giving her a crippled range, she needs beefier compensation and ratio numbers that don't hinge on building pure AP. With her miserable ratios on everything but Twin Fangs, she cannot afford to build anything but AP in order to make her poisons have impact. This is where the AP boosts in her passive cripple her, as their bonus coupled with the AP she is building is the only way to make her damage output viable. If the passive power shackles are dropped, her ratios increased, coupled with single target and short range poisons, this would be ideal for her to build tankier and be more balancing, as she can build better defenses to take advantage of getting in close without having her be entirely destroyed by close range burst.

The poison theme is definitely part of why I loved the feel of playing Cass, but it was by no means all of it. Personally I'd be willing to trade some of her old early game power for some later game power, but never at the expense of her strong AoE damage -- Q and W are just too meaningless without E.

While we are on the topic of "feels", I still really absolutely hate the CDR in the passive (I hate the entire idea of stacks on Cass to unshackle her as well) at the expense of increasing base cooldowns of her poison spells. While it might alleviate the primary concerns you had in the rework, which seems to be curbstomp her early game, it makes her kit *feel* super awkward when she can no longer permanently keep an enemy poisoned... as the primary poison champ in the game. This makes her E feel janky until you get max stacks and can keep an enemy permanently poisoned again.

Also true, but I guess those two arguments are completely unrelated.

I'd prefer for any changes made to Cass to push her towards her old lane bully pattern (BTW, I recently played against Syndra. Even at her strongest, Cass was never any worse than Syndra at lane bullying, so I'm not sure why Cass was a problem and Syndra isn't)  as well as make her more poisonous, but I haven't put much thought into which one I would prefer if I had to choose only one...so hopefully I don't have to choose!

Hopefully someone can correct me if I'm wrong, but I *think* I've heard some reds say that Cassiopeia was not much else than a lane bully; her late game was pretty weak, so it isn't so much of her lane bullying being problematic so much as she had trouble scaling into late game, unlike Syndra who still has her long range, utility, and crap tons of damage. I *think* maybe the changes were initially supposed to make Cassiopeia strong in the late game, and then the idea occurred to make her incredibly strong late game, and thus her early game was butchered to try to balance this.

I could be way off, but sort of trying to fill in the gaps of my understanding with a story :3.

I haven't heard that, but it's believable. Her late game was weak because she was squishy and prone to getting bursted down, with only conditional hard CC and a minor slow. She still had a fair amount of damage, but couldn't apply it in most situations. So I could buy that's what Riot, Stashu specifically, was planning, considering their love of fallback mechanics for newer champions/updates.

I'm just not sure why they decided to completely reverse her power curve.

Yea, I think my story would have made sense if they just kept her laning phase more or less untouched (minor compensatory nerfs?) and just gave her more tools to apply her damage late game; I might be getting too carried away here but it's possible that they reversed her powercurve to try to balance her? 

I'm just speculating here:

When I first played Cassiopeia (like a year ago, before all the reworks), I didn't understand her at all and actually thought she was supposed to be a hypercarry sort of mage with the way her E resets worked. Trying to put myself in Stashu's shoes; it's possible he saw the potential for improving her late game by revolving around the E reset mechanics, so decided to focus on that. With a lot of recent designs, Reds seem to be trying to push what's possible in the game, so it's possible that Stashu really wanted to push this late-game direction of Cassiopeia since he saw a lot of potential in this direction, thus the passive was born. When he took a step back, however, he saw that her kit was pretty stacked at this point, and had to nerf everything to try to keep her balanced (undershooting as is typical of releases these days because it's probably healthier for the game to have underpowered champions steadily buffed rather than some broken champion released and everyone panics).

Again, all just speculation, but if this is remotely true, perhaps it would be best to look towards something like making Cassiopeia scale less aggresively into late game, keeping some buffs to her laning, but giving her more late-game utility, like Syndra or Orianna have?

Possible. I know that most of her kit was nerfed in order to compensate for her passive, just looking at the numbers for the base damage and ap ratio on her abilities says that much. But I don't feel like they were just looking for giving her tools to apply her damage. The only 'tool' she got was the healing on her E, the rest was simply number changes (lower ap ratios to compensate for the higher amount of AP she's getting).

>Again, all just speculation, but if this is remotely true, perhaps it would be best to look towards something like making Cassiopeia scale less aggresively into late game, keeping some buffs to her laning, but giving her more late-game utility, like Syndra or Orianna have?

I'd be down for that concept. Personally, I'd start by removing the cast time and/or the facing requirements on her ult. It does not need both, and I'm not even sure it needs either.

>I'd be down for that concept. Personally, I'd start by removing the cast time and/or the facing requirements on her ult. It does not need both, and I'm not even sure it needs either.

I think it'd be kind of cool to get, instead of a slow if the enemy is facing the other way, a fear. That way she at least gets some consistent hard-CC with her ult, and I feel like it fits thematically (I'd be terrified if I heard her scream behind me). This also gives her a bit more of an opening to get her damage down without worrying as much about the enemy just turning around and blowing her up.

I think the main issue here is that Cassiopeia's rework changed multiple aspects of Cassiopeia that made many players uncomfortable, some for just a single reason and others...for multiple reasons. And then there are those who dislike it for one reason, but think they dislike it for multiple reasons because a single changed thing screws with the other things as well.

>  Even at her strongest, Cass was never any worse than Syndra at lane bullying

How can you ever have Cass at her strongest? Either your team, or the enemy team already surrendered the second you reach 500 stacks...

It's been like that for the majority of my Cass games. I do well, enemy team surrenders. Do not so well, your team surrenders even if you vote "NO" yourself. Ironically I've ever become "Goddessiopeia" in a Dominion game...the least likely map to reach 500 stacks.

I disagree. A DoT character needs to be at least one of three things in order to be effective and not useless:

--Hyper mobile (Teemo) so the character can duck in and out of combat to trade effectively
--Super tanky (Singed) so the character can survive long enough for his/her poisons to deal enough damage
--Extra-long ranged (Cassiopeia) so the character can stay out of reach of retaliation that would kill him/her

The character does not need to be all three of these, and in fact is most balanced and effective when he/she is crippled in one of the other departments (Singed's range is nonexistant, Teemo's tankiness is nonexistant, Cass's tankiness is nonexistant) but that must be coupled with one of the above extremes. 

What would Singed be like if he wasn't super tanky? What would Teemo be like if he wasn't super mobile? That's what you've done to Cass by making her so E-focused. You've taken away her primary asset and have not compensated by removing her greatest weakness. That is why she feels like shit to play, even if she's actually strong: being a close-ranged mage does not fit with being a super-squishy DoT character. It wouldn't feel right even if E one-shot tanks. Power is irrelevant here, she feels like shit because her current design is shit.

This is a matter of archetype expression.

While I agree with you that a DoT champion doesn't necessarily have to have all those qualities, however, the archetype of a Poison-centric mage, imo, SHOULD come with a few fantasy fullfilling baggage that people desire from it.


1) They're often "cowardly" individuals who relies on Poison to achieve what they could not physically achieve without it.

e.g - [Fiora's Father...The Nameless Mr. Laurent](http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Fiora/Background) is a dirty cheat and a coward...he can not possibly win a proper duel.

This is why I (and probably just me) feel that being a super-late game god is ill-fitting of the archetype. I feel that an individual who relies on poison should never have any ultra strong-point as that's too "combative" by nature. Too Vayne-like. 

2) If one's poison is **gaseous in nature**, having powerful AoE effect IS kind of what you'd want if you're spreading it all over. Think Koffing/Weezing and how that Pokemon fills whatever room he's in with his smoke, yet outside of like, Sludge, he doesn't have much else to look forward to in terms of a 1v1 situation.


As for short cast-times, yeah I agree it has little to nothing to do with poisoning, but rather **I think** it's a reaction to the fact that her MS boost comes from needing to land a skillshot on an opponent whereas other champions simply have to press a button. I can live with her being as she is with her MS buff being much less free, but probably not as the AP Rambo she currently is where getting up close and personal is her only pattern. But this is getting more on the "balance"-side of things and I'm more concerned with gameplay

As a counterpoint of what many of us want poison to be, **yet can totally work**. I guess there is the case of a venomous spider. If we have a venomous spider champion, she can be 

* melee
* single-target damage in nature as her leaps in to sink her fangs into a single target


In short, I guess a DoT-assassin is where a single-target short-ranged poison-champion could work out. HOWEVER, when I look at Cassiopeia filling the air with her poison gas and all her surly lines, I get something completely different from that.

THAT is why I feel Cassiopeia could be more of a **long-ranged AoE DoT champion** who possesses a **Ziggs-like ability to defend herself**(read:basically none at all) if engaged upon.


Do you see a difference then? Cassiopeia is a noblewoman, she is represented by an animal normally associated with cowardice and treachery. People see her as spreading a gaseous poison (btw, her Q's CD is longer than it's poison duration...). For someone like that, E offers too much all-inning power whereas it feels like such an archetype should be more focused on staying far away to inflict her vile poison while her henchmen (allied players) keeps the enemy in place. Her E should be the final *"dagger in the back"* where she sneaks in to deal the killing blow.
